Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Exploiting microbial hyperthermophilicity to produce an industrial chemical

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264052/1264053
Kelly/Adams

The development of microbial metabolic engineering has largely been based on a limited number of recombinant hosts (e.g., Escherichia coli, Saccharomyces cerevisiae) because of the substantial knowledge of the physiology of these microorganisms and availability
of associated molecular genetic tools. However, as metabolic engineering is directed at more and more innovative bioprocessing objectives, there is a pressing need to expand the range of potential microbial hosts. Because extremophiles are already endowed with properties that are amenable to the harsh conditions characteristic of industrial processes, it makes sense to develop metabolic engineering capabilities for this group of microorganisms. This direction would have been implausible until very recently, but newly developed molecular genetic tools and genomics studies have opened up the prospects for metabolic engineering of extremophiles. As such, this proposed project will demonstrate the efficacy of metabolically engineering the hyperthermophilic archaeon, Pyrococcus furiosus, which grows optimally at 100°C. To demonstrate that this microorganism can, indeed, be metabolically engineered, the work will build upon recent success in temperature-dependent biochemical processing and will now produce a specialty chemical, succinate, from cellobiose and maltose. Genes encoding transporters and metabolic enzymes identified from less thermophilic organisms with optimum temperature values near 70°C will be imported into a recombinant P. furiosus strain. Novel approaches for gene regulation and product formation that strategically exploit hyperthermophilicity will be utilized to optimize yields and efficiencies for bioproduct formation near 70°C. Providing a paradigm for metabolically engineering a hyperthermophilic host to produce a non-physiological product will pave the way for thermally-based, bioprocessing opportunities.

Broader impacts will result from the interdisciplinary training of students in molecular biochemistry, functional genomics and biomolecular engineering for studying extremophile biology and biotechnology. Two undergraduate researchers will be recruited during each fall semester and be supported subsequently for a summer research experience in the PI's laboratories (one biochemist at UGA and one chemical engineer at NCSU). These students will spend two weeks during the summer at the other collaborating lab to foster interdisciplinary training. All students on this and related projects at NCSU and UGA will participate in an annual extended 'Hyperthermophile Group Meeting' during the summer to be hosted at NSCU and UGA on an alternating basis. This will foster interdisciplinary training and collegiality, as well as provide a mechanism for exchange of research ideas and methodologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Industrial biotechnology to date has focused on the use of well-studied microorganisms, such as Escherichia coliand Saccharomyces cerevisiae (yeast), as platforms for producing fuels and chemicals through modifying their metabolism by genetic engineering. While the tools for manipulating these microbes are well-established, their normal life styles are typically far removed from the formation of intended biotechnology targets. Alternatively, less studied but potentially impactful microorganisms, are often ignored. This group includes the so-called ‘extremophiles’, which inhabit normally inhospitable natural biotopes, or extreme environments (e.g., high salt levels - halophiles, low pH - acidophiles, high temperature – thermophiles). Extremophiles have the potential to be used in settings that are close to normal chemical processing conditions which, among other aspects, are less sensitive to contamination, a major problem in biomanufacturing.

The use of extremophiles in industrial biotechnology would be impossible if not for the recent development of genetic engineering capabilities for some of these microorganisms. The extreme thermophiles, the focus of this project, grow at temperatures above 70°C and in some cases could be metabolically engineered to produce chemicals and fuels with the recent availability of molecular tools to do so. The NSF Award to Professors Robert M. Kelly at North Carolina State University and Michael W.W. Adams at the University of Georgia enabled efforts to demonstrate that extremely thermophilic microbes can be genetically engineered to produce fuels and chemicals. Pyrococcus furiosus, an extreme thermophile that grows optimally in boiling water (100°C) was engineered to produce ethanol and butanol (both useful as liquid transportation fuels), carbon monoxide (a gaseous fuel molecule) as well as 3-hydroxypropionate (a chemical that can be used to make polymers). Sulfolobus acidocaldarius, a microbe that grows well in hot acid, was engineered to use elemental sulfur (normally a by-product of petroleum and natural gas processing) to meet its energy requirements which could lead to producing important fuels and chemicals from carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas. In addition, we metabolically-engineered the extremely thermophilic biomass-degrading bacterium, Caldicellulosiruptor bescii, to produce the biofuel ethanol. By establishing these paradigms for genetically-engineering extremely thermophilic hosts to generate non-physiological products, we are paving the way for thermal-based, bioprocessing opportunities. 

Consequently, the most important outcome of this project was the establishment of extreme thermophiles as metabolic engineering platforms for industrial biotechnology and our achievements will lead to innovative ways to produce key fuels and chemicals. Graduate and undergraduate students working on the project benefitted from the interdisciplinary interaction between chemical engineering and biochemistry laboratories. The project will lead to further development of non-model microorganisms as tools for converting renewable feedstocks into valuable products.
